titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Memorabilia FA437
titlestmt.author: Finding prepared by Eva Grizzard

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-08-26 17:53:26 -0400.

did.unittitle: Memorabilia

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: All inquiries to view memorabilia items require permission from RAC, and advanced notice of up to one week. Individual items may be restricted from scholarly access at the discretion of RAC. Please see RAC Head of Archival Services for details.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Memorabilia collection is arranged by subject, in 10 series primarily based on central Rockefeller family members. Each individual object has been assigned a unique number 1-8999.

Series 1: Nelson A. Rockefeller (NAR) (objects #1 – 999) Series 2: John D. Rockefeller Sr. (JDR SR) (objects #1000 – 1999) Series 3: John D. Rockefeller Jr. (JDR JR) (objects #2000-2999) Series 4: John D. Rockefeller 3rd (JDR 3RD) (objects #3000-3999) Series 5: Laurance S. Rockefeller (LSR) (objects #4000-4999) Series 6: David Rockefeller (DR) (objects #5000-5999) Series 7: Rockefeller University (objects #6000-6999) Series 8: Harold P. Fabian (objects #7000-7999) Series 9: Rockefeller Foundation Decorations (objects #8000-8999) Series 10: Ford Foundation (object # associated with RAC accession number).

Any Rockefeller family members/interests not specifically listed above or relating to the Rockefeller family in general, as well as miscellaneous/unidentified objects, are included with the JDR SR series, #1000-1999.

The objects themselves show evidence of various attempts at organization by RAC over the years; many have numbers and inscriptions from past cataloguing which may refer to their original collection information. No new stickers were added to the objects, but some stickers have been left on items rather than risk damage to the item through removal of the (inappropriately glued) labels. When possible, pieces have been identified with acid-free label tags on strings. A majority of the documents have been labeled in pencil on the back of the paper, and are also in labeled folders or envelopes. Albums and books have ID hangtags, and foam or plastic-wrapped items are marked on their exterior wrapping.

On the NAR material, the rectangular stickers with rounded corners have the correct, current identification number. Any stickers, labels or numbers that don’t correspond to the new four-digit ID system are irrelevant, inactive and discontinued. Most labels are written with the initials of the relevant family member (i.e. “SR #1010” or “LSR #4004”), but some may just have the four-digit ID number (#3020).

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p:
In 2009, the RAC began an effort to expand and enhance physical and intellectual control of the mixed-media artifacts and commemorative objects found throughout many of the archival collections. A large volume of non-document materials had already been separated from the body of various archival collections and stored in an attic, which, over the years, was sporadically inventoried.
In a previous cataloguing project, all of the Nelson Rockefeller (NAR) memorabilia was described and numbered consecutively, with about 985 pieces. Materials relating to John D. Rockefeller Sr. and John D. Rockefeller Jr. were both given separate numbering systems, while the rest of the Rockefeller members’ items had never been inventoried.
The 2009 project, adopted the unique numbering of the NAR series (#1-999) and added the other major Rockefeller family figures, and small volumes of memorabilia from the Rockefeller University, Rockefeller Foundation, Ford Foundation and other RAC archival holdings, in subsequently numbered series (see Arrangement note). All other previous numbering is inactive and discontinued.

processinfo.head: Processing note
processinfo.p: Item-Level processing of the Memorabilia was conducted by Eva Grizzard in 2009-2011, guided by processing and preservation decisions from Carol Radovich, Assistant Director, Head of Archival Services, and Robert Battaly, Assistant Director, Head of Processing, as well as Susan Havranek, Lead Archivist, Collections Management. Several part-time assistants and interns also assisted with this project, including Liam Berkowitz, Lydia MacDougal, and Marissa Vassari.
This finding aid was prepared by Eva Grizzard, 2009-2013, with data migration into the RAC collection management system and content revisions by Robert Battaly, 2014.

processinfo.head: Housing and Preservation note
processinfo.p: Due to the nature of memorabilia, certain steps have been taken to ensure the long-term storage and preservation of select items. Several of the oversized items within this collection are too large for standard vault shelving. When applicable, items have been placed in special boxes or wrapping, and may be stored offsite.

Additionally, some large framed items have been interfiled with other oversized framed works, but retain their Memorabilia collection labels and object numbers. All items marked “DEFRAMED” were removed from a frame to facilitate long-term preservation. Large documents and flat art pieces have been relocated to the flat files, separated by series. Letter and legal size pieces are housed primarily in archival document boxes.

processinfo.head: Processing note
processinfo.p: Processsing of the Memorabilia collection improved archival storage and space efficiency at RAC, while helping to further develop institutional archival practices for the broad range of special formats and media found in this collection.

The material relating to Nelson A. Rockefeller (“NAR”) was the first series to be processed, because it was a large grouping that had been separated and inventoried by an archivist when the materials were originally received. The numbering and classification system for the NAR materials were then adopted for the rest of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Encompassing a wide range of media and styles, including plaques, paintings, photographs, textiles, costumes, and audiovisual materials, the memorabilia primarily documents over 100 years of history of the Rockefeller family and several of their philanthropic endeavors including the Rockefeller University and Rockefeller Foundation. The collection also consists of memorabilia from the Ford Foundation and Harold P. Fabian papers.

A majority of the items can be traced to a specific Rockefeller family member, but not necessarily to a definitively verifiable provenance or originating collection, so a subject-based arrangement was adopted.

scopecontent.head: Glossary
scopecontent.p: A controlled vocabulary was introduced to simplify the naming of various formats within the Memorabilia collection. The glossary below provides this terminology, which lists generalized definitions as pertaining only to the Memorabilia.

list.head: Glossary
list.item: A/V – A limited selection of audio-visual materials.
BOOK - Published books, privately published books and commemorative books.

CITATION - Honors conferred or bestowed, in the form of a document indicating or symbolizing the award or remuneration. Citations are not mounted items, but sometimes accompany a medal or commemorative object.

COMMEMORATIVE - Miscellaneous items produced, issued, or worn to honor a person, event, or occasion which are not unto themselves specific awards; includes paperweights, sculptures, shovels, flags, etc; also includes most campaign-related materials.
CORRESPONDENCE - Any forms of addressed and written communication sent and received, including letters, postcards, memorandums, notes, telegrams, or cables.
DIPLOMA - Certificates, degrees and honorary degrees bestowed from universities and educational institutions.
DOCUMENT - Any paper item that is not a citation or correspondence, including printed items, books, pamphlets, newspaper, etc.

MEDAL - Small metal decorations and ornaments created with a commemorative or honorary purpose; any award that is not a plaque or document; often but not always refers to ornaments worn on the individual, such as royal appointments or pins which might hang on ribbons for the neck or shoulder.
MEMORIAL - Any memorial objects that are not specifically applicable to other categories.
MISCELLANEOUS - Any object or document not included in previous categories and/or lacking accompanying information, including art.
PICTURE - Any non-photographic, two-dimensional image, including paintings, cartoons, blueprints, etc.
PHOTOGRAPH - Any photographically-reproduced image, whether an original or a duplicate. Photographs may be positive or negative, opaque or transparent, printed on any medium.
PLAQUE - Any mounted award, citation, or honors conferred, sometimes paired with a token which relates to the document.
